results.title: 1914 - 1918 The Great War and the Shaping of a Century
results.creator_credit: Carol Sennett, Carl Byker and BBC
results.brief_description: This is a seven part series from the BBC looking at the Great War and the shaping of a century through the words of those who endured it. The series is narrated by Dame Judy Dench. The first part, Explosion, contains the first three episodes and details the build up to the War and the first years of the campaign. The second part, Legacy, expplores the War and the consequences of the end of the War, including the Treaty of Versailles and the seeds that were sown for the second World War.
results.title_for_label: 1914 - 1918 The Great War and the Shaping of a Century

The second part, Legacy, expplores the War and the consequences of the end of the War, including the Treaty of Versailles and the seeds that were sown for the second World War.

results.title: 1914-1918 : explosion
results.creator_credit: Margaret Koval, Imperial War Museum (Great Britain), BBC-TV and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “1914 - 1918 The Great War and the Shaping of a Century”.
This is a seven part series from the BBC, looking at the Great War and the shaping of a century through the words of those who endured it. With the use of many diaries, letters and film we re-experience a war that involved the people of 5 continents. Narrated by Dame Judy Dench, we also hear voice-overs by Ian Richardson, Martin Landau, Wendy Craig, Tim Pigott-Smith, Chris Fairbanks, Jeremy Irons, Liam Neeson, Tom Fleming, John Shrapnel, Malcolm McDowell and Imogen Stubbs reading passages from personal letters and diaries. Many historians including the series historian Dr. Jay Winter provide valuable background information relating to events and battles which occurred. Tape One-Explosion contains the first three episodes of this remarkable series. Episode 1-EXPLOSION, explores the cultural backdrop to the outbreak of war. Episode 2-STALEMATE, as the war began many experts thought technical advances in weaponry would bring a quick victory but armies resorted to trench warfare on the Western Front. Episode 3-TOTAL WAR, the battle at Gallipoli in 1915 confirmed that European conflict had expanded into the first truly global war. Many Empires and Nations would be forever changed, the social context altered and shattered, a lost generation of men and ideals. Such dramatic events that would shape and define peoples lives for the rest of the 20th Century.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Margaret Koval, Imperial War Museum (Great Britain), BBC-TV and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The film contains eclectic footage from a family holiday in New Zealand, a Sherbert concert in Ararat, a Dumbo film premiere promotional parade in Ballarat, and some black and white footage of a surburban house being constructed.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:05:42:00 brief tourist shots in New Zealand: hot springs, tehokowlitu-a-tu, memorial gateway, Maori soldiers
00:07:21:00 shot of a drive-in
00:08:04:00 Astor theatre in Ararat; Sherbert concert footage
00:11:23:00 black-and-white footage of house being built
00:17:52:00 Dumbo film promotion in street parade Ballarat

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film has two sequences. Firstly, a debutante ball circa 1960s, where we see the very nervous young couples as they descend a staircase to be introduced to the committee of older people overseeing the proceedings. Jack captures the rigorous nature of a debutante presentation with its strict dress code and rules, and somewhat stultifying atmosphere.

Secondly, Jack captures entertainment at an ice rink that includes several different acts.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected hightlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards, ‘Vegas News 70’ and ‘Delighted Debutants’ (sic)
00:00:18:00 the debutantes line up for a formal photograph with their flower posies in the shape of the Freemasons ‘square and compass’ symbol
00:00:39:00 organisers inspecting the debutantes where we see 1960s style hair styles held in place by hair spray
00:00:60:00 dignitories enter the ball in a parade and the women are presented with flower posies as they line up on the stage ready for the debutantes presentation
00:01:32:00 two children appear as mascots, slightly confused
00:01:53:00 the first of the young women debutantes, in their white formal ball dresses, appear on the stage with their partners, young men in formal evening suits
00:02:43:00 negotiating the stairs, no hands on the rails
00:02:58:00 the curtsy and the bow to the dignitories
00:03:54:00 the musicians
00:04:28:00 the Freemasons society symbol above the dancers
00:05:03:00 members of the band playing their instruments
00:05:35:00 stepping through a particularly painstaking dance
00:06:25:00 the formalities over, debutantes and their partners relax at the tables in the ballroom
00:07:00:00 the brass section of the band
00:07:07:00 dancing what appears to be the ‘Pride of Erin’ waltz
00:07:46:00 various skaters performing on ice
00:09:37:00 two ice skaters dressed in a cow costume
00:12:18:00 an ice skater leaping through a ring of fire

results.title: Beautiful Ballarat
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The collection is filmed on 16mm and 9.5mm film and the films can sometimes be a bit damaged and shaky.

This film presents scenes from in and around central and suburban Ballarat in the 1940s to 1950s.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 title card “Beautiful Ballarat”
00:00:29:00 1950s tramcar passing old Ballarat post office on Sturt Street, Ballarat
00:00:58:00 FJ holden Radio Cabs lined up
00:09:13:00 snowfall 1940s Ballarat town centre and surrounds
00:11:03:00 odd looking snowman
00:11:14:00 snowball fight between grown men with some funny ham acting
00:11:26:00 nice shot of RADIO CABS neon sign lit up at night
00:11:30:00 lights on buildings celebrating the municipality of Ballarat 1855–1955 “100”

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents a glimpse of a somewhat nostalgic version of Australian suburban family life as it was in the 50s and early 60s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 children playing with sprinkler and toys 1950s
00:02:19:00 leaving hospital with baby
00:03:39:00 a 1950s Christmas scene; children with toys
00:04:59:00 brief shot of Queenscliff with kids riding in Cobb & Co. horse-drawn carriage
00:06:53:00 girl jumping on a trampoline with pier in the background – trampoline park with interesting “trampolines” sign
00:08:59:00 nice shot of toddler waddling towards the camera
00:12:54:00 backyard children’s birthday party
00:17:05:00 young girl using a hula hoop in a paddock
00:18:02:00 toddler gets a home haircut

John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents a glimpse of a somewhat nostalgic version of Australian suburban family life as it was in the 50s and early 60s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

group.title: [John Anderson Home Movie Collection]

results.title: [Yoram Gross Films film posters]
results.brief_description: Reproductions of posters for Yoram Gross animated films: “Art Alive” ; “The Adventures of Blinky Bill” ; “Blinky Bill’s Extraordinary Adventures” ; “Flipper & Lopaka” ; “Old Tom” ; “Samuel & Nina” ; “Skippy” ; “Tabaluga” ; “Dot and the Kangaroo” ; “Epic” ; “Joseph the Dreamer” ; “The Seventh Match” ; “The Camel Boy” ; “The Little Convict” ; “The Magic Riddle” ; “Blinky Bill’s White Christmas”.

results.title: Yoram Gross interview collection
results.brief_description:
Contains:
1.’Channel 9 News’ item: Blinky Bill
2. ‘TVTV’ program (Sept. 1993): Yoram Gross, Blinky Bill, Guy Cross, Robyn Moore, Robert Smit
3. ‘7.30 Report’ ABC: Keith Scott, Yoram Gross, Blinky BIll, Dot and the whale, Guy Cross
4. Dot & Kangaroo, Athol Henry, Animators, Dot goes to Hollywood
5. Guy Cross Film music
6. ‘Channel 7 News’ and ‘A Current Affair’ (June 1994): Blinky Bill versus Senator McGaurin
7. Ray Martin interviews Yoram Gross, Dot and Keeto
8. ‘Small Business Show’ Channel 9: Yoram Gross interview, Sandra Gross interview
9. News article on the Childrens Film Festival
10. Childrens Film Festival interview with Yoram Gross
11. Channel 9 News: Childrens Film Festival, Bob Hawke, Guy Cross
12 ‘Today Show’ Channel 9: Interview with Yoram Gross, Around the World with Dot
13. ‘Today Show’ Channel 9 (May 1985): Interview with Yoram Gross, Epic (poor image quality)
14. ‘C’mon Kids’: making Dot & Keeto with Athol Henry
15. ‘11am’ Channel 7: Dot & Keeto, Around the World with Dot, Dot Goes to Hollywood, Sarah
16. ‘Tutti’ SBS: Blinky Bill, Sarah, Bandstand
17. ‘Midday with Derryn Hinch’: Robyn Moore interview

results.title: Blinky Bill production featurette
results.brief_description: Documentary capturing the production process behind the creation of a Blinky Bill animated film. Includes storyboard and cel animation, sound recording, filming live action footage, creating models, music composition and sound recording.Yoram Gross, John Palmer (writer), Frank Hammond (cinematographer), Ray Nowland (art director), Guy Gross (composer) and other crew are also featured discussing their work.
